responses_by_article.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
responses_by_article.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Diverse client segments with varied usage patterns: (1) Low-breadth but high-depth usage clients (low frequency but complicated modules), (2) High-breadth but low-depth usage clients (high frequency but simple modules), and (3) Clients demanding access from odd times or obscure locations
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'The third challenge resides in clients' varied usage of software services. Whereas some clients may exhibit low-breadth but high-depth usage (i.e., low frequency of service usage but complicated software modules required), others may register the opposite usage pattern (i.e., high frequency of service usage but simple software modules required) or demand access to required services at odd times or from obscure locations'

responses_by_article.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
responses_by_article.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: B2B organizations with varying IT capabilities and security requirements - ranging from small-medium sized customers without IT infrastructure to large organizations with existing IT departments and internal data centers
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 4: 'within the first six months we realized that this does not work with smaller customers who do not have servers in the firm. It became clear that 90 percent of our customers wanted to use this through a public cloud' | Page 5: 'Low initial costs in software renting enabled to expand the customer base from large-sized customers toward small and medium-sized customers (Firm D)' | Page 5: 'customers who had already invested in IT infrastructure and their own IT personnel, they saw traditional software licensing as a more attractive choice'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Small and medium size businesses with less than 1000 employees, served through Value-added-Resellers (VAR) who provide customized products and services. This segment represents the largest customer base where ERP Co works closely with partners.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 5, Section 5.1: 'The second segment is small and medium size business with less than 1000 employees, where ERP Co works closely with their partners, all what they refer to as value added resellers. Here, all the sales go through ERP Co partners, which could be platinum partners that only work for ERP Co and build their services around ERP Co products, or gold partners that mainly work with ERP Co but also engage with other businesses, or smaller partners and resellers that represent ERP Co or their products in micro markets and local markets around the country.' | Page 5: 'VAR is a critical part of ERP Co's business ecosystem, as they are in direct charge of selling to the largest customer segment, the small and medium size businesses.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Making a Business Out of (Predictive Application Management in) the Fog
responses_by_article.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Asset Manufacturers are the most detailed segment for the License-based model, specifically those producing hardware components and systems to build Fog infrastructures (e.g., CISCO, Dell) and smaller start-ups like Nebbiolo Technologies. For the Freemium model, Application Operators are most detailed, particularly those producing customized hardware (e.g., Philips Hue, Ikea Tradfri).
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'Asset Manufacturers (AMs) which are producing hardware components and systems (e.g., access points, routers, switches) to build Fog infrastructures (e.g., CISCO [15] and Dell [16]), and often take care of deploying and managing their equipment for other service providers (e.g., Telco operators)' | Page 3: 'smaller start-up companies (e.g., Nebbiolo Technologies [32]) are pioneering the manufacturing market to produce their Fog-tailored hardware and platforms' | Page 3: 'Among them, those which are also producing customised hardware to run part of their application (e.g., Philips Hue, Ikea Tradfri), represent a particularly interesting segment'
